Fig. 1 Durability test of 12 %Ni/MgAl-LDO catalyst in the amination of acetone at the high conversion levels (A) and at the low conversion levels (B). (A) Reaction conditions: 120 °C, molar ratio of NH3 to acetone: 7:1, H2: 40 ml/min, residence time: 6.42 s. (B) temperature: 120 ℃, molar ratio of NH3 to acetone: 6:1, H2: 20 ml/min and residence time: 1.82 s. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 XRD patterns of NiMgAl-LDH (A), NiMgAl-LDO (B), fresh and used 12 %Ni/MgAl-LDO (B) catalysts. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 SEM images of fresh (a, b) and used (c, d) 12 %Ni/MgAl-LDO, TEM (e) images, HRTEM image (f), HAADF-STEM image (g) and the Ni (h), Mg (i), Al (j) and O (k) mappings of fresh 12 %Ni/MgAl-LDO. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 H2-TPR characterization of samples. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 XPS spectra of Ni 2p (A, B) for the samples. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 In-situ DRIFT spectra of acetone amination over 12 %Ni/MgAl-LDO. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Calculation results of the imine molecule adsorbed on the top (1), bridge (2), and hollow (3) positions of Ni (1 1 1) facet: perpendicular state (a) and parallel state (b). Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Calculation results of H2 adsorbed on the top (1), bridge (2), and hollow (3) positions of Ni (1 1 1) facet: perpendicular state (a) and parallel state (b). Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Calculation results of the target product IPA adsorbed on the top (1), bridge (2), and hollow (3) positions of Ni (1 1 1) facet: perpendicular state (a) and parallel state (b). Fig. 9 Fig. 10 Calculated energy profiles for the amination of acetone to IPA on the Ni (1 1 1) facet. School of Chemical Engineering, Xiangtan University Xiangtan 411105 PR China The direct amination of alcohols (ketones) with ammonia to primary amines is a promising route. In this work, an environmentally friendly and efficient method for the synthesis of isopropylamine from the reductive amination of acetone over hydrotalcite-derived Ni/MgAl-LDO catalyst was successfully developed. The results demonstrated that the 12 %Ni/MgAl-LDO catalyst showed outstanding catalytic activity and stability, and 99.8 % of acetone conversion with 93.4 % of isopropylamine selectivity was still maintained over 100 h at 120 °C. The characterization results verified that 12 %Ni/MgAl-LDO catalyst possessed the highly dispersed and uniform Ni nanoparticles, which were responsible for its outstanding catalytic activity and stability. Futhermore, the DFT calculations results indicated that Ni sites of Ni (1 1 1) facet were acted as the catalytic active sites for reductive amination of acetone. This study provides a simple, low-cost and efficient approach for the production of isopropylamine, with promising prospects for industrial applications. Graphical Abstract Keywords Ni/MgAl-LDO Acetone Isopropylamine Reductive amination Ni (1 1 1) facet Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Primary amines are crucial chemicals for manufacturing dyes, pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, biologically active compounds and surfactants [1–5]. For example, the low-carbon aliphatic primary amine, isopropylamine (IPA), as the key intermediate for the production of drugs, herbicides and pesticides [3], has attracted considerable attention. Generally, primary amines are synthesized by the hydrogenation of nitrile [6–8], ammonolysis of haloalkanes [9] and ammonolysis of olefins by hydrogenation [10–12]. However, these methods have been progressively phased out in the industry due to the disadvantages such as high cost, low yield, strong corrosion, difficult separation and unfriendly for environmental. Notably, some researchers indicated that the direct amination of ketones and/or alcohols to primary amines is becoming more and more popular for the industry [13–15]. At present, for the synthesis of IPA, most methods use the isopropanol (IPO) or acetone as raw material. Undoubtedly, the catalyst is crucial in the reductive amination. According to previous reports, the active components of catalysts for the alcohols (ketones) amination are generally metals such as Ni, Cu, Co, Au, Ir, Ru, Pt and Pd [16–22]. Shin [23] investigated that the amination of IPO on Ni/γ-Al2O3, and 32.6 % conversion of IPO with 82 % selectivity to IPA was achieved at 150 °C. Göbölös et al. [24] reported that the skeletal nickel catalysts gave 98 % of acetone conversion with 85 % of IPA selectivity at 170 °C and 0.8 MPa. Shen [25] employed the Ni/LaAlSiO catalyst in gas-phase amination of IPO, and 85 % of IPO conversion with 98 % of IPA selectivity was obtained at 180 °C and 2.0 MPa. Shin [26] reported that 94 % of IPO conversion with 80 % of selectivity to IPA was achieved over Ni/γ-Al2O3 (17 wt% Ni) catalysts at 170 °C and 0.1 MPa. Hong [27] reported that the Ni-Fe alloy catalysts performed 86.7 % of selectivity to IPA in the IPO amination. Bond [28] employed the supported Ru/SiO2 catalyst in amination of IPO, and the IPO conversion and IPA selectivity were 16 % and 36 % at 160 °C and 0.421 bar, respectively. Fu [29] reported the catalytic amination of IPO and acetone on supported Ru/TiO2 to produce IPA. The results showed that 89 % of acetone conversion with 88 % of selectivity to IPA was obtained over at 200 °C and 0.1 MPa. Nevertheless, it can be seen that the synthesis of IPA with high selectivity remains a significant challenge due to the presence of some side reactions during the amination process [30]. Thus, it is necessary to explore an efficient catalyst with remarkable catalytic performance and stability in the amination of acetone to IPA [31–34]. In fact, the noble metals catalysts were restricted in industrial applications owing to the high cost and challenging recycling processes. Therefore, many researchers have focused on the design of non-noble metal catalysts with outstanding catalytic properties for acetone amination. In recent years, the layered double hydroxides (LDHs) have garnered significant attention for their favorable chemical property with adjustable structure and thermal stability [35]. LDHs are further calcined to the layered double oxides (LDOs) [36], which possess well dispersed metals as catalytic active sites that have received extensive applications [37]. Herein, we have afforded the novel and efficient approach for the highly selective reductive amination of acetone to IPA by employing the hydrotalcite-derived Ni/MgAl-LDO as an efficient and stable catalyst. 2 Experimental section The reagents and instruments, experimental procedure, preparation and characterization of catalysts, In-situ DRIFT and computational details can be found in the Supporting Information (SI). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic properties of diverse catalysts in reductive amination Table 1 summarized the results of the amination of acetone to IPA over the different catalysts. Obviously, the reductive amination hardly occurred in the absence of catalyst (Entry 1). Moreover, such as SBA-15, SiO2 and γ-Al2O3 also had no catalytic activity in the amination of acetone. However, only 4.5 % of the acetone conversion to IPO was obtained over MgAl-LDO (Entry 5). To improve the catalytic activity of catalyst, Cu, Co, Fe or Ni metals as the active components were introduced into the catalytic amination. It could be seen that the 12 %Ni/MgAl-LDO catalyst demonstrated the outstanding catalytic properties with 99.8 % conversion of acetone and 93.4 % of selectivity to IPA (Entries 6–9). On this basis, the catalytic activities of Ni/MgAl-LDO catalysts with varying Ni loadings were further tested (Entries 12–14). The results indicated that 12 % of Ni loadings on MgAl-LDO gave the promising catalytic activity. To further explore the impact of different carriers on the catalytic properties, the 12 %Ni/γ-Al2O3 and 12 %Ni/SiO2 catalysts were prepared. Although the conversion of acetone reached to 90 %, the selectivity to IPA was only 69.3 % and 53.6 %, respectively, suggesting that the support played a crucial role in the reductive amination of acetone (Entries 10 and 11). Moreover, the impacts of reaction parameters on the amination of acetone over 12 %Ni/MgAl-LDO were further optimized and the obtained results were exhibited in Fig. S1. In addition, in order to further realized the influences of reaction parameters, the reaction parameters at the low conversion levels were also studied, as shown in Fig. S2. According to the single factor experimental results, 99.8 % conversion of acetone and 93.4 % selectivity to IPA were obtained over 12 %Ni/MgAl-LDO catalyst under the optimal reaction conditions were 120 °C of temperature, 7:1 of the molar ratio of ammonia to acetone, 40 ml/min of H2 flow rate and 6.42 s of the residence time. 3.2 The durability of 12 %Ni/MgAl-LDO in acetone amination reaction In order to further evaluate the stability of 12 %Ni/MgAl-LDO in the reductive amination, a long-term durability experiment was performed. Fig. 1A showed that 99 % conversion of acetone with 93 % selectivity to IPA was maintained after running for over 100 h at 120 °C. Moreover, the stability of catalyst at the low conversion levels was also tested, as shown in Fig. 1B. The results exhibited that 12 %Ni/MgAl-LDO catalyst showed outstanding stability in the catalytic amination of acetone to IPA at the low conversion levels. Furthermore, the following characterizations of XRD ( Fig. 2) and XPS (Fig. 5) results also demonstrated that there was no obvious difference between fresh and used 12 %Ni/MgAl-LDO catalysts. These results fully illustrated that 12 %Ni/MgAl-LDO catalyst showed outstanding stability in the catalytic amination of acetone to IPA. 3.3 Characterizations of catalysts Fig. 2 depicts the XRD patterns of NiMgAl-LDH, NiMgAl-LDO，fresh and used 12 %Ni/MgAl-LDO catalysts. In Fig. 2A, the diffraction peaks at 11.2°, 22.8°, 34.8°, 39.3°, 46.9°, 60.3° and 61.9°, which correspond to the planes of hydrotalcite (0 0 3), (0 0 6), (0 1 2), (0 1 5), (0 1 8), (1 1 0) and (1 1 3), respectively, are observed in the NiMgAl-LDH sample, suggesting that the hydrotalcite catalyst with good crystallization and complete structure is successfully prepared (PDF#54–1030) [38]. Fig. 2B demonstrates the XRD patterns of NiMgAl-LDO, fresh and used 12 %Ni/MgAl-LDO catalysts. The NiMgAl-LDO catalyst shows the diffraction peaks at 37.2°, which is assigned to the reduction of NiO or NiAl2O4 (PDF#04–0835, PDF#81–0710) [39]. The diffraction peaks at 37.2°, 43.5°, 63.3°, 75.5° and 79.4°, which are assigned to NiO (1 1 1), NiO (2 0 0), NiO (2 2 0), NiO (3 1 1), and NiO (2 2 2), respectively (PDF#04–0835). For fresh and used 12 %Ni/MgAl-LDO catalysts, the formation of well-crystallised metallic Ni on MgAl-LDO can be inferred from the characteristic diffraction peaks of Ni (1 1 1), Ni (2 0 0) and Ni (2 2 0) at 44.2°, 51.8° and 76.4°, respectively (PDF#04–0850) [40]. Notably, Fig. 2B indicated that the XRD patterns of the fresh and used 12 %Ni/MgAl-LDO samples were identical, indicating that the 12 %Ni/MgAl-LDO catalyst exhibited the wonderful stability in the reductive amination. In addition, Fig. S3 displayed that all the samples exhibited the representative IV isotherm curves with an apparent hysteresis loop, suggesting the major existence of mesopores in the Ni/MgAl-LDO samples [41]. Table S1 summarized that 12 %Ni/MgAl-LDO catalyst had the smallest pore size and pore volume, illustrating that some Ni nanoparticles were well dispersed in the pores of MgAl-LDO [27,42]. The fresh and used 12 %Ni/MgAl-LDO catalysts presents the “petal-like” morphology （ Fig. 3a-d）, which is typical of the hydrotalcite morphology. For 12 %Ni/MgAl-LDO catalyst, the average size of the Ni nanoparticles is approximately 4.8 nm (Fig. 3e) and the lattice spacing is 0.204 nm (Fig. 3f), corresponding to the Ni (1 1 1) facet [43]. The TEM-mappings of 12 %Ni/MgAl-LDO in Fig. 3g-k further demonstrate that the uniform Ni nanoparticles are highly dispersed on MgAl-LDO. These results full prove that 12 %Ni/MgAl-LDO catalyst has the unique microstructure, maybe which is reason for the outstanding catalytic properties and stability in the amination of acetone to IPA. Fig. 4 represents the H2-TPR profiles of Ni/MgAl-LDO samples with different Ni loadings. For the MgAl-LDO carrier, no reduction peaks are found, suggesting that the reduction temperature of MgO and Al2O3 is very high [44]. For Ni/MgAl-LDO samples, the reduction peaks observed around 450–600 °C are ascribed to the reduction of surface NiO (Ni2+) to Ni0 [45–47]. The reduction peaks at 600–900 °C are belonged to the reduction of NiO particles that have a strong interaction with the carrier, as well as the reduction of the spinel (NiAl2O4) [42]. Therefore, NiO species in the Ni/MgAl-LDO catalysts are only partially reduced at 550 °C, which indicates the partial Ni2+ species still present in the catalyst. It can be seen that 12 %Ni/MgAl-LDO catalyst exhibits the lower reduction temperature for NiO species. Moreover, in order to further verify the metal dispersion of Ni/MgAl-LDO catalysts, the dispersion of Ni metal (D Ni) was tested by H2 chemisorption, as shown in Table 2. The results show that 12 %Ni/MgAl-LDO catalyst exhibits the largest H2 uptake quantity, metallic surface area and the best nickel dispersion, which demonstrates the Ni0 species as the main catalytic active sites favor the hydrogenation process of imine in reductive amination of acetone. The XPS patterns of Ni 2p for Ni/MgAl-LDO samples with varying Ni loadings are presented in Fig. 5. For the Ni 2p3/2 spectra in Fig. 5A, the characteristic peaks at binding energies 852.1, 855.3 and 861.4 eV are belonged to Ni0, Ni2+ species and satellite peak, respectively [48–52]. Table S2 summarizes the content of Ni0 in Ni/MgAl-LDO catalysts with varying Ni loadings. These results demonstrate that the content of Ni0 is the highest in 12 %Ni/MgAl-LDO, indicating that it can provide more active Ni0 species and is good for the amination reaction of acetone [53,54]. Moreover, there are identical in the XPS patterns of the fresh and used 12 %Ni/MgAl-LDO catalysts in Fig. 5B, suggesting that 12 %Ni/MgAl-LDO has promising stability in the acetone amination, which is corresponds with the XRD results (Fig. 2B). To further explore the reaction mechanism for the amination of acetone with NH3 over 12 %Ni/MgAl-LDO, the In-situ DRIFT spectra were performed, as shown in Fig. 6. The peak at 1720 cm−1 is assigned to the stretching vibrations of CO bond (acetone) [55]. The peaks at 1365 and 1648 cm−1 are ascribed to the vibrations stretching of =N-H and CN bonds [56–58], respectively, which indicates the formation of imine as key intermediate by the condensation reaction of acetone with NH3. The peak at 1447 cm−1 is assigned to the vibrations stretching of C-N bond (IPA) [59]. The bands around 1610 and 3400 cm−1 are attributed to the stretching vibrations of -NH2 group (IPA) [59]. The bands around 2875 and 2957 cm−1 are ascribed to the C-H stretching vibration [60]. These results demonstrated the synthesis routes of IPA through the condensation of acetone with NH3 to imine, which was further hydrogenated to IPA. 3.4 DFT calculations Fig. 6 shows the key intermediate imine is formed by the condensation reaction of acetone reacts with NH3 over 12 %Ni/MgAl-LDO catalyst. It has been reported that the condensation reaction of ketone with NH3 to form imine is a fast equilibrium reaction [61,62]. According to the characterization results of 12 %Ni/MgAl-LDO catalyst, the adsorption models of the intermediate imine molecule on the Ni top, Ni-Ni bridge, and Ni-Ni-Ni hollow positions of Ni (1 1 1) facet in the perpendicular or parallel state were established, as shown in Fig. 7. The calculated structures models of Ni (1 1 1) facet and imine molecule are displayed in Fig. S4 and Fig. S5, respectively. Fig. 7 exhibit the adsorption energies of imine molecules on the Ni (1 1 1) facet are −1.21, −1.12, −1.21, −0.74, −1.11 and −1.09 eV, respectively. Therefore, the adsorption energy of the imine molecule adsorbed on the Ni top and Ni bridge positions of Ni (1 1 1) facet in the perpendicular state is the lowest (-1.21 eV), indicating that the adsorption configurations of imine molecule on the Ni top and Ni bridge positions of the Ni (1 1 1) facet in the perpendicular state are relatively stable. These results reveal that the imine molecule is more effective to be activated on the Ni top and Ni bridge positions of Ni (1 1 1) facet in the perpendicular state. Fig. 8 displays the adsorption models of H2 molecule on the Ni top, Ni-Ni bridge, and Ni-Ni-Ni hollow positions of Ni (1 1 1) facet in the perpendicular or parallel state. The calculated adsorption energies of H2 on the Ni (1 1 1) facet are −0.10, −0.21, −0.13, −0.21, −0.14 and −0.97 eV, respectively. Thus, the adsorption energy of H2 molecule adsorbed on the Ni-Ni-Ni hollow position of Ni (1 1 1) facet in the parallel state is the lowest (Eads=-0.97 eV), indicating that the H2 molecule is preferentially adsorbed and activated at the Ni-Ni-Ni hollow site of Ni (1 1 1) facet in the parallel state. Therefore, the H2 molecule can be more easily dissociated into active hydrogen (H*) on the Ni-Ni-Ni hollow site of the Ni (1 1 1) facet in the parallel state. The optimized structure of the target product IPA molecule is displayed in Fig. S6 . Fig. 9 exhibits the adsorption models of the IPA molecule on the Ni top, Ni-Ni bridge, and Ni-Ni-Ni hollow positions of Ni (1 1 1) facet in the perpendicular or parallel state. The calculated adsorption energies of IPA on the Ni (1 1 1) facet are −0.67, −1.10, −1.11, −1.12, −0.92 and −0.16 eV, respectively. Therefore, the adsorption energy of the IPA molecule adsorbed on the Ni-Ni-Ni hollow position of Ni (1 1 1) facet in the parallel state is the highest (-0.16 eV), indicating that the target product IPA is more easily desorbed from the Ni-Ni-Ni hollow position of Ni (1 1 1) facet in the parallel state. According to the in-situ DRIFT results (Fig. 6) and the previous literature [29,63], the relevant radical reactions for the amination of acetone and the corresponding structures of the initial, transition and final states on Ni (1 1 1) facet were proposed in Fig. S7. The calculated energy distributions of different reaction paths for the catalytic amination of acetone to IPA are presented in Fig. 10. It has been reported that the following two reaction paths for the amination of acetone are possible: (i) the nitrogen atom of the adsorbed imine can bond with a H atom to generate the intermediate (CH3)2CNH2 via TS-1a ((CH3)2CN(···H)H, 1.76 eV), the resulting intermediate (CH3)2CNH2 can be hydrogenated on the carbon atom by TS-2a ((CH3)2C(···H)NH2, 3.64 eV) to obtain the target product IPA (see the black line in Fig. 10) and (ii) the carbon atom of the adsorbed imine can combine with a H atom to generate the intermediate (CH3)2CHNH via TS-1b ((CH3)2C(···H)NH, 1.95 eV), and the resulting intermediate (CH3)2CHNH can be hydrogenated on the nitrogen atom by TS-2b ((CH3)2CHN(···H)H, 1.70 eV) to obtain the target product IPA (see the red line in Fig. 10). According to the calculation results of the activation energy of two reaction pathways, it can be concluded that the hydrogenation of imine to IPA apparently proceeds by the intermediate (CH3)2CNH2 (Reaction Path 1 in Fig. 10). 3.5 Reaction mechanism There are some reports on the amination reaction mechanism of alcohols or carbonyl compounds to amines [64–66]. Based on the obtained results in this work, the possible reaction mechanism for the amination of acetone with NH3 to IPA is suggested in Scheme 1 . Firstly, acetone reacted with NH3 to form the intermediate imine, which was further hydrogenated to form target product IPA. In addition, a small amount of IPO was obtained by the hydrogenation of acetone with hydrogen under the present reaction conditions. 4 Conclusions In summary, a simple and efficient method for the gas-phase catalytic amination of acetone and ammonia to IPA was successfully developed over 12 %Ni/MgAl-LDO in this work. The results indicated that the 12 %Ni/MgAlO catalyst showed the outstanding catalytic activity and stability, and 99.8 % conversion of acetone with 93.4 % selectivity to IPA was maintained after running for 100 h at 120 °C. The characterization results proved that 12 %Ni/MgAl-LDO catalyst possessed highly dispersed and uniformly sized Ni nanoparticles, which were responsible for its outstanding catalytic activity and stability. Furthermore, the in-situ DRIFT spectra elucidated the catalytic amination mechanism of acetone with NH3 over 12 %Ni/MgAl-LDO. The DFT calculation further confirmed that the imine as the key intermediate was adsorbed and activated on the Ni top and Ni bridge positions of Ni (1 1 1) facet in the perpendicular state. The present study introduces a low-cost and environmental-friendly approach for the catalytic amination of acetone to IPA and has potential application prospects. coredata.dc:description: The direct amination of alcohols (ketones) with ammonia to primary amines is a promising route. In this work, an environmentally friendly and efficient method for the synthesis of isopropylamine from the reductive amination of acetone over hydrotalcite-derived Ni/MgAl-LDO catalyst was successfully developed. The results demonstrated that the 12 %Ni/MgAl-LDO catalyst showed outstanding catalytic activity and stability, and 99.8 % of acetone conversion with 93.4 % of isopropylamine selectivity was still maintained over 100 h at 120 °C. The characterization results verified that 12 %Ni/MgAl-LDO catalyst possessed the highly dispersed and uniform Ni nanoparticles, which were responsible for its outstanding catalytic activity and stability. Futhermore, the DFT calculations results indicated that Ni sites of Ni (1 1 1) facet were acted as the catalytic active sites for reductive amination of acetone. This study provides a simple, low-cost and efficient approach for the production of isopropylamine, with promising prospects for industrial applications.
